Before the virologic era, equine epizootics highly suggestive of influenza were documented repeatedly, beginning in 1299 with an equine epizootic
43 coincident with a widespread European influenza epidemic. In this epizootic: “the horse carried his head drooping, would eat nothing, and ran from the eyes”.
22 Twenty‐nine years later, in 1328, an equine epizootic in Yemen, later attributed to influenza,
1 ,
56 coincided with a major European epidemic of apparent influenza. In 1404, yet another equine epizootic was associated with a major European influenza epidemic.
